summary: unlicensed replication in B-cells can manifest clinically as infectious mononucleosis. productive replication in epithelial cells can be associated with immune suppression in AIDS patients. latent infection is linked to all forms of EBV-associated cancers, including nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) a robust in vitro method to mimic differentiation-induced lytic reactivation in polarized epithelia, in primary or immortalized airway epithelial cell lines, could significantly advance our interrogation of EBV pathogenesis in preneoplastic mechanisms. the conventional method to reactivate EBV is by chemical induction with histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitors and protein kinase C inhibitors. the air-liquid interface (ALI) culture method establishes apical and basolateral surfaces by seeding cells on a collagen-coated transwell membrane. once an intact epithelium is established, the apical medium is removed and cells are fed through a porous membrane from the basolateral surface. the method can also be applied to immortalized cell lines (26, 27). epithelial cells are seeded on a collagen-coated transwell membrane. there are a limited number of authenticated NPC cell lines that continue to harbor latent EBV in culture. the HK1 cell line originated from a differentiated NPC tumor biopsy specimen and infected with a recombinant (Akata) EBV strain. the HK1-EBV cell line was established by in vitro infection of a recombinant EBV originating from the EBV Akata strain (38). in proliferating monolayer cultures, the HK1 cell line does not show induction of the lytic cascade and expresses a type II latency profile characterized by the expression of EBNA1, EBER1/2, LMP1, LMP2A, LMP2B, and BART transcripts (38). in this immunoblotting for expression of early protein zebra,
